skill.name: migrating-to-db
skill.description: Expert guidance for migrating Logseq graphs from Markdown (MD) format to the new Database (DB) format. Auto-invokes when users ask about MD to DB migration, converting graphs, import options, data transformation, or compatibility between Logseq versions. Covers migration strategies, common issues, and best practices.
skill.summary: Expert guidance for migrating Logseq graphs from Markdown (MD) format to the new Database (DB) forma...
skill.author: C0ntr0lledCha0s

security_audit.summary: This is a read-only documentation/guidance skill for Logseq MD to DB migration. It provides informational advice only and uses only safe tools (Read, Grep, Glob, WebFetch, WebSearch). The static findings are all false positives: command examples are documentation (not execution), URL references are legitimate resources, and Datalog schema identifiers were misclassified as cryptographic algorithms.

content.user_title: Migrate Logseq Graphs from MD to Database
content.value_statement: Logseq users need clear guidance when transitioning from Markdown files to the Database format. This skill provides step-by-step migration planning, backup strategies, troubleshooting for common issues, and Datalog query examples for validation.
actual_capabilities: Guides users through Logseq MD to DB migration planning step by step
Provides pre-migration checklists for backing up and auditing graph structure
Explains migration strategies: big bang, parallel operation, and selective migration
Troubleshoots common issues like lost property types, tag confusion, and broken references
Shares Datalog query examples for validating migration results
Documents feature comparisons between MD and DB versions
limitations: Does not execute migration operations or modify user graphs
Cannot access or migrate private or encrypted Logseq data
Does not provide real-time support during active migration
Cannot guarantee compatibility with future Logseq DB versions

use_cases.title: Plan Graph Migration
use_cases.description: Prepare for DB migration by auditing tags, properties, and namespaces before making changes

use_cases.title: Validate Migration Results
use_cases.description: Use Datalog queries to verify pages, properties, and references transferred correctly

use_cases.title: Choose Migration Strategy
use_cases.description: Select the right approach for large graphs with active content and complex structure

prompt_templates.title: Start Migration
prompt_templates.prompt: I want to migrate my Logseq graph from Markdown format to Database format. What are the key steps and decisions I need to make?

prompt_templates.title: Backup Strategy
prompt_templates.prompt: How do I properly back up my Logseq graph before migrating to DB version? Include bash commands.

prompt_templates.title: Fix Issues
prompt_templates.prompt: After migrating to Logseq DB, my property types are wrong and some page references are broken. How do I fix this?

prompt_templates.title: Validate Results
prompt_templates.prompt: Write Datalog queries to check that all pages transferred correctly, identify orphaned blocks, and verify property migration in my DB graph.

output_examples.input: How do I migrate my Logseq graph from Markdown to Database format?
output: Pre-Migration Checklist: Backup your graph, audit pages/properties/tags, identify migration decisions
Export from MD: Settings ‚Üí Export ‚Üí Export to EDN
Migration Options: Convert tags to classes or keep as references, flatten or preserve namespaces, infer or text property types
Post-Migration: Keep MD graph as backup, validate with Datalog queries, monitor for issues

output_examples.input: What should I do before migrating my Logseq graph?
output: Create a timestamped backup of your entire graph folder
Review pages with namespaces and templates that may behave differently
Audit property formats and tag usage patterns
Decide which tags will become classes and plan your property schema

output_examples.input: My queries stopped working after migration to DB
output: MD and DB versions use different attribute names in queries
Rewrite queries using Datalog syntax for the DB format
Use the validation queries to check that pages and blocks transferred correctly

best_practices: Always create a timestamped backup before migrating your Logseq graph
Start with a small subset of your graph to test migration before full conversion
Document your tag and property structure before migration to ensure consistent conversion
anti_patterns: Migrating without a backup of your original MD graph
Converting all tags to classes without planning inheritance hierarchy
Deleting your MD graph immediately after migration before validating all content

faq.question: Is Logseq DB version stable for production use?
faq.answer: Logseq DB is still in alpha. Data loss risk exists and some features like whiteboards are not yet available.

faq.question: What happens to my tags during migration?
faq.answer: Tags can be converted to classes with inherited properties or kept as simple page references.

faq.question: Can I migrate back to MD format after switching to DB?
faq.answer: No direct migration path exists from DB back to MD. Keep your MD graph backed up.

faq.question: Will all my queries work after migration?
faq.answer: No. MD and DB versions use different attribute names. Some queries need Datalog rewrite.

faq.question: Do plugins work with Logseq DB?
faq.answer: Plugin compatibility varies. Some plugins may not work yet in the DB version.

faq.question: What is the best strategy for large Logseq graphs?
faq.answer: For large graphs, consider parallel operation. Keep MD graph active while gradually moving content.
